I.6	Executive Summary
At the New River Water Treatment Plant facility, WVAW handles chlorine for the purpose of disinfecting and treating drinking water.  OSHA and EPA consider chlorine as a hazardous chemical. I.5.1 Worst-case Release Scenario for Chlorine

The worst-case scenario at our water treatment facility involves a failure of a single one (1) ton cylinder holding approximately 2,000 lbs of liquefied chlorine gas under pressure, resulting in a release with vaporization of approximately 500 pounds of chlorine gas. In this scenario, the chlorine is released as a vaporizing liquid inside a completely enclosed chlorine storage room in our water Chemical Feed building. The containment provided by the building mitigates the release. Such building confinement reduces the release rate of chlorine vapor directly to the outdoors. According to the software modeling, since this facility is located in a rural area, the toxic cloud potentially formed by the evaporating chlorine should not reach nearby public receptors based upon the calculated distance of 0.5 miles to off-site end points.
Access to the chlorine storage room is electronically controlled and monitored to prevent unauthorized access. WVAW also utilizes the SCADA system to monitor and remotely control the chlorine feed system. 

Numerous administrative controls are in place to prevent a release of this type. Controls include container design, storage, operation, maintenance and inspection; container repair and emergency response equipment; and personnel training conducted in accordance with regulatory requirements, chlorine industry standards and practices, local standard operating procedures, and our company's corporate policies and procedures, which are strictly enforced at the water treatment Plant.

This facility is also regulated under the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program rules (40 CFR 68) as a result of managing chemicals in excess of its Risk Management Program threshold quantity.  Under the EPA rule, chlorine is classified as a regulated substance with a threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds.  The effective date for the EPA rule was June 21, 1999.
As the major elements of the OSHA and EPA regulations are very similar, WVAW has taken the approach of developing a combined program that accommodates both the OSHA and EPA requirements in an integrated manner. This document provides the program management procedures.
I.4	5 Year Accident History - 40 CFR 68.42
As of March 2022, the West Virginia American Water New River Water Treatment Plant has had no reportable releases of chlorine.
I.5	Off-Site Consequence Analysis - 40 CFR 68.39
The Risk Management Program rule requires facilities to assess a range of potential releases including the worst-case release for every extremely hazardous chemical and more likely release scenarios.  The assessment includes dispersion modeling of worst-case and alternate case release scenarios, identification of all potentially affected populations, and identification of potential environmental damage.  
For toxic substances, which are normally gases at ambient temperature and handled as liquids under pressure, the worst-case release is defined as the release of the contents of the largest single vessel within 10 minutes as gas.    Additionally, an alternative release that is defined as a scenario that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.

WEST VIRGINIA-AMERCIAN WATER COMPANY
NEW RIVER REGIONAL WATER TREATMENT PLANT 
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

I.	PSM/RMP PROGRAM OVERVIEW

I.1	RMP Management System

The West Virginia American Water (WVAW) New River Water Treatment Plant has developed a Risk management Plan (RMP) as required by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) as defined in 40 CFR 68.10.   The Production Supervisor oversees the overall responsibility for the compliance of the New River Water Treatment Plant's RMP.  The assigned Operational Risk Management/Health & Safety personnel for West Virginia American Water will also provide support for the elements of the program.  Additional West Virginia American Water personnel will be assigned to assist in the compliance of the program as needed.

I.2	Facility Description
The New River Water Treatment Plant has a design capacity of 4.0 MGD.  It is a surface water treatment plan with its source water being the New River.  The facility is located in Fayette County in the State of West Virginia.  The chemical treatment process utilizes the following chemicals: polyaluminum chloride, chlorine, fluoride, potassium permanganate, corrosion inhibitor, powered activated carbon, and non-ionic polymer. 
I.3	Program Information
WVAW operates the New River Water Treatment Plant which is regulated under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) rule (29 CFR 1910.119) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule (40 CFR Part 68).  The facility is subject to the OSHA and EPA standards because the chlorination process contains a regulated chemical in excess of the OSHA threshold quantity.  Under OSHA Process Safety Management, chlorine is classified as a highly hazardous chemical (HHC) with a threshold quantity of 1,500 pounds, OSHA standard requires regulated facilities to develop comprehensive management programs and emergency action plans.
